title: Will more than 6,000 new battery electric vehicles be registered in Germany in the third quarter of 2016?
preds: A local Mitsubishi dealer estimated that they sell eight normal cars and then a hybrid; pure battery cars much much less. Subsidy applications are reported to be approx 3000 nationwide. » Nach acht normalen Fahrzeugen verkauft Mitsubishi-Händler ... einen Hybridwagen, ... Die Nachfrage nach reinen Elektroautos sei noch geringer. Die würden im ländlichen Raum wenn als Zweitwagen genutzt. „Zum Beispiel für kurze Strecken und zum Einkaufenfahren“, sagt er. « http://www.merkur.de/lokales/wolfratshausen/wolfratshausen-ort29708/e-autos-kaum-interesse-landkreis-6787756.html
2016 is not a great year for electric vehicles.
Misleading question...Germany has 25K in electric cars already registered. New registrations defined how?
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
August data shows still very weak interest.

Fully electric vehicles have lately sold <1,000 units per month in Germany. Sales in July were reported at 915 units, which gives an estimated 2,745 fully EV cars sold in the 3rd quarter of the year, more than 2x lower than necessary to meet the 6,000 car goal. http://evobsession.com/electric-car-sales-germany-july-2016/
I hope this forecast compensates my error with the Emmy's  ;-)
According to the general news and GJP consensus, and time decay.
Seems my former rational had very different number than your sources. Checking some more sources it would be a huge increase in sales, and seems unlikely.
too expensive, no incentive, too few chargin stations

The number of electric cars sold as be growing substantially, last here there was a total of almost 5500 units sold in the same trimester, growing this to 6000 is a smalls step, and the german goverment just aunched new incentives to buy electric cars in May.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
http://evobsession.com/electric-car-sales-germany-july-2016/ 6 months worth of EV sales only hit 6194. Even though sales will likely increase, it isn't looking good based on current sales.
There have been a few recent informative comments. Dropping to 1% from 9%.
Half year data far from promising.

July was 785; 
3rd quarter so far : 1680

Upto about 1680 at end of August so highly unlikely, but Mirai sales in US (large corporate, government puchase still a possibility)
@ts2m

I guess Moltke, our most accurate German forecaster, would write to Mack Institute: »No American business plan survives the first contact with the German consumer.« Actual numbers
+ 785 July (48 less than in June, or minus 6%)
+ 895 August (110 more than July, or plus 14%)
+
======
1,680 Source: German car registry, KBA Wracked business plan to 6000 cars:
+ 1200 July (400 more than in June, or +50%)
+ 2000 August (800 more than the hypothetical July, +66%)
+ 2800 September (800 more than the hypothetical August, or +40%)
======
~ 6000 I just learned about the ACCORD model, thanks to the Wharton school online videos (from the same university where the Mack Institute sits, they might tear down their silos):  -- To a German car driver, the (A)dvantage of a pure battery-driven car is far less clear, if not non-existent; short distances isn't exactly what a buyer expects from "better" technologies;  -- the pure-battery car is not (C)ompatible with what the German driver is already doing (filling at the gas station, in few minutes; compared to 30 minutes charging), the mere idea of having a cable going out of your door to the car is nuts, too, only garage owners would do it;  -- all car magazines throughout the country (C)ommunicate skepticism about pure battery cars; -- you also can't (O)bserve other car electric drivers' takeaways, what people want is status and prestige, currently you get raised eyebrows;  -- the perceived (R)isks . . . manufacturers announced to bring better performance, soon, as such why wasting money on cars that become obsolete, soon;  -- (Divisibility) would imply that people can selectively try out electric and conventional drives over any distance, and Germans actually want to drive to Mallorca, Prague, Stockholm, minimally to the alps or North Sea! They can do it with hybrid cars, and hybrid cars sold +84% this last month.  ACCORDingly ... 1680 cars, to see Germans piling up over 4000 cars in September is akin to Martians landing, not only on earth, but also transforming themselves into muscle cars.

895 in August. If I'm not mistaken, it means that September needs > 4320 registered vehicles. http://www.kba.de/DE/Presse/Pressemitteilungen/2016/Fahrzeugzulassungen/pm25_2016_n_08_16_pm_komplett.html?nn=716864

I am living and working in the automotive sector in Germany. The subsidy program has been poorly received by Germans. I think this is a cultural problem. For a German, an electric vehicle is not a satisfied car (Germans found Audi, Mercedes, Porsche, BMW, ...).
Therefore I see a minimum chance to reach 6,000 new registered battery vehicles.

Check back when they get the July numbers up. http://www.kba.de/DE/Statistik/Fahrzeuge/Neuzulassungen/MonatlicheNeuzulassungen/2016/201606GV1monatlich/201606_nzbarometer/201606_n_barometer.html;jsessionid=E329FC27316228259A5AFE74A03F2EB1.live21302?nn=653844

785 for first month of third quarter (thanks to @ts2m for link), should mean the game is over, given registrations couldn't even beat June's 833, and August is a particularly poor month seasonally (http://www.tradingeconomics.com/germany/car-registrations)

Supposedly, around 1,000 of the 5,000 or so global orders for the newest model year of the BMW i3 were made in Germany, according to unnamed sources at BMW.
http://evobsession.com/bmw-i3-sales-rose-germany-following-electric-vehicle-subsidy-implementation/

Blog post circulating the German early-adopter audiences http://zoepionierin.de/renault-zoe-ein-fazit/
-------
Earlier I assumed young well-off engineering types of people at uni cities to be buyers: here, a girl talking about costs and vacations with a Renault, and the daily 100+ km commuting for three years.
Slow progres in the applications for the subsidy (only few hundred after more than one month). Slightly up from the crowd because I bet for last minute "bolw-out Sale".
With a decline in sales for may there was a sale increase in june. But i think most people who wanted to take advantage of this did so tight away.

Q2/2016: 2.025 units sold -> to meet 6.000 new units sales has to triple from Q2 to Q3 
Q3/2015 -> 2.722 -> to meet 6.000 new units sales has to increase with 120% from Q3/2015. There was no such increase since 2013 (Q3/2012 to Q3/2013).
Source: http://www.kba.de/DE/Statistik/Fahrzeuge/Neuzulassungen/MonatlicheNeuzulassungen/monatl_neuzulassungen_node.html  Based on actual status of application of the subsidy (July 21st) there are 819 applications for battery electric vehicles. 
Source: http://www.bafa.de/bafa/de/wirtschaftsfoerderung/elektromobilitaet/publikationen/emob_zwischenbilanz.pdf The processing of the application will take less than 4 weeks. 
Source: http://www.finanznachrichten.de/nachrichten-2016-07/37851260-praemie-fuer-e-autos-reicht-laut-bafa-chef-bis-2019-003.htm  Assuming the same rate of applications and that processing will last 2 weeks approx. 2.730 applications can be taken into account for Q3. Even if they are adding to a Q3/2015 level (2.722 units) the number for Q3/2016 is approx. 650 units short to 6.000.
Remote chances...only 1622 vehicles sold in Q2...but the EV incentive program started in May will uplift sales but not to the extent of 6000

2015 statistics total number of cars = 44403124; new cars = 3M (+1.3%); el cars 18948 (+55.9%);  Buying a new car (P)=6.8%; el car = 4%; New el car = 29% (8705);  assume grouth @ 1.3% -->  11317/year, 2829/quarter. assume growth in el cars of 55.9% --> 4411 new electric cars in a quarter

News from the German experiment: - in 12 days (July 2nd--14th) there had been 150,000 downloads of the application form
- 936 actual received submissions during the same period; note that all purchases from May 18th to July 14th would qualify Further considerations; casual reading of the German news gives me the impression that industry experts and car nerds qualify the car's achievable distances as "disappointing" to "useless". Some, here, may speculate that the next spike for car sales could start with gov't purchases ... well, one thing, I found in the German FAQ, is that subsidies will not be granted to gov't buyers, including state-owned entreprisis, local gov'ts or police. The subsidy is strictly for private persons, enterprises ..
Enough offers in mIddle and lower car classes, enough role models in upper class
No recent news of car sales increasing.

Some recent numbers about the 'kaufprämie': 936 requests so far (14 July),  625 for battery electric vehicles. Most requests (about 2/3) are from private persons, the rest mostly from companies. Source (German): http://www.automobilwoche.de/article/20160714/AGENTURMELDUNGEN/307149907/kaufpramie-fur-elektroautos-vor-allem-privatleute-wollen-kaufpramie-fur-elektroautos
From what I can tell the subsidy hasn't been approved yet and I have yet to see June registrations.
Slow growth and continuing low oil prices make this less likely.

Relying heavily on the information from @Rene, @praedico and @ts2m, as I am struggling to get the links, we have 833 registered in June (when the subsidies were in play even if you could not apply for them), which is nowhere near the run-rate required to get to 6,000. Even if you add the 1,000 reported orders for the new BMWi3, which was released earlier than my previous forecast expected, and assume no cannabilism of current run-rate registrations, as well as assuming delivery of all of them during Q2, you only get 3,500. So dropping forecast down to 6% (to account for a sudden surge in registrations, law of small numbers).
Upping this slightly based on Reuters BMW report

"4.357 reine Elektrofahrzeuge bewirkten im ersten Halbjahr einen Neuzulassungsanteil von 0,3 Prozent" So, 4.357 new battery electric vehicles in the first two quarters. EV volumes in Germany have dropped the last couple months but can probably be attributed to the coming EV incentive program.  I'm forecasting a weak euro in the third Q...1.05 to 1.07 for Sept 2016, SP500 debt downgrade for EU debt, and negative social mood = decreased spending. maintaining 5% http://evobsession.com/europe-electric-car-sales-report-may-2016/
http://www.ev-volumes.com/
Berlin (dpa) reports: Starting this weekend, applications for subsidies are going to be accepted (only cars bought after May 18th qualify).

Essentially the question is asking if EV sales will rise by 185% in Germany within a year.
To get a base rate, this report on the US concludes
http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy15osti/63263.pdf
According to this report "A $1,000 increase in tax credit value is associated with a 2% to 10% change in per-capita BEV registrations". This varied by model.
In the Netherlands the incentive structure is a bit more complicated but "In total for 2015, plug-in vehicle reached 43,300 units, +183% over 2014" 
http://cleantechnica.com/2016/03/07/ev-sales-22-of-car-sales-in-netherlands-in-december-2015/
Initial crude calculations that 6000 euro incentive would mean a possible 12 to 60% within a year in the US and 184% in NL. So 185% is a long shot but possible.  
There a few specific German factors:
- this looks like it comes off the tag price of the car so it is likely to have more of an effect than tax credit.
- new models from German manufacturers are coming on stream, the US example shows models have an effect on sales
- Range anxiety is less of an issue that in the US due to higher population density
- Germans aren't like the Dutch on cars - the land of BMW 7 series and no speed limits on many motorways won't be crazy for EV

Consensus has dropped quite a bit after my initial forecast of 20%.
I have no problems dropping to 15% on this question just to keep pace.
Down 5% on expectation mattresses will have more gold stashed under them after the Brexit vote.

Given the considerable barriers remaining to battery-electric vehicle adoption and the fact that the €4000 subsidy only defrays about 10% of the price of the domestic models* I somehow doubt the quarterly sales are going to triple this year. *I was able to find price info on German websites for the Nissan Leaf and Tesla Model X; the former cost actually somewhat less than the domestic models, but not very much so, and the latter cost very much more with a base price of over €96,000
Germans have an appetite for latest technology
German people more confident of that vebhicle
About 16k-20k annually considering continued growth trajectory. Growth is slowing slightly, thus 6k a 1/4 seems to ambitious.
Government subsidy likely to increase take-up. UK (similar size pop) electric car buying is running at around 2500 per month with no govt subsidy.
Even with the subsidy, it is hard for sales to pick up from around 2100 of the 1st quarter to the 6000 needed

The German public focuses on safety this fits into that cultural thinking IF the infrastructure can support it as well.   I give it more than 50% chance for the culture impact, but believe that the other types of impact - speed and access to power will matter as well.

Perhaps if the government actually does subsidize battery electric vehicles this could happen, but without that incentive, it appears unlikely to hit 6,000 in the third quarter. Also, there are now 4 German automakers developing electric vehicles, so many buyers may wait to see what Daimler, especially, comes out with, which won't be until 2017.

Last year 12400 electro vehicles were registered, and aroudn 3500 in the first 5 months of 2016. 
I'm assuming that petrol prices will stay at current low levels for most of 2016. 
I still need to understand whether Jul-Sep was in the last years typically is a stronger sales quarter than the first 2 quarters.
For now I give 6000 new registrations over Jul-Sep a low probability.
Slowdown in May, 3524 cumulatively from jan to May, inclusive; 2016-05 alone 588. Rate in April was 700+ per month. Source, KBA.

This March was actually lower year-over-year with last March. February was an impressive 72% over last year, but was still small and had fallen slightly last year over the year before. 6000 would be a more than 100% increase over last year, which seems unlikely unless gas prices skyrocket.

In Q3 of 2015, only 2.7k electric vehicles were registered. This would mean that YoY growth would have to be over 100%, which is unlikely. Also, growth in the current year has been relatively stagnant, although this could be because of consumers waiting for the launch of the subsidies.  How much do the subsidies save as a percentage of the list price, however? Let's assume the the avg. price is 20k for an electric vehicle. Then the subsidy is about 20% off of the avg price, so I assume that translates into a 20% boost in demand over the regular growth. If regular growth for 2016 is 50% (which seems high), then total growth will be 2.7k * 1.5 * 1.2 = 4.9k, which doesn't meet the cut. Also, gas prices are super low and Germany also shut down nuclear plants recently, so price for electricity has gone up, both factors that increase the relative cost of electric vehicles.
Subsidies are always a good way to make things happen yet this will require greater than a year-on-year doubling of sales which remains a big ask.

It is too early for incentives in Germany to go into effect to see that big of an uptick in sales. Additionally, the EURO is actually much weaker relative to the JPY and USD since q3 of last year. I believe the uptick will take place in Q1 2017.

The Global EV Outlook 2016 study noted, "The year 2015 saw the global threshold of 1 million electric cars on the road exceeded, closing at 1.26 million [100 times more than in 2010]. This is a symbolic achievement highlighting significant efforts deployed jointly by governments and industry over the past ten years. In 2014, only about half of today’s electric car stock existed. In 2005, electric cars were still measured in hundreds." Source: International Energy Agency, Global EV Outlook 2016* Furthermore, the study noted, "New registrations of electric cars increased by 70% between 2014 and 2015, with over 550,000 vehicles being sold worldwide in 2015. The market shares of electric cars rose above 1% in seven countries: Norway, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark, France, China and the United Kingdom. Market shares reached 23% in Norway and nearly 10% in the Netherlands in 2015. China emerged as the main electric vehicle market: its booming electric car sales were larger in 2015 than in the United States." Also electric vehicle charging infrastructure saw significant growth: "Indeed, not only did electric car sales surge in 2015, but so did infrastructure for EVs, with total electric vehicle supply equipment reaching 1.45 million units, against 820,000 in 2014 and roughly 20,000 in 2010. The number of publicly accessible chargers grew 71% last year, including 63% more fast chargers."
https://evannex.com/blogs/news/118365957-international-energy-agency-electric-vehicle-battery-costs-rapidly-declining-tesla-cited-as-leading-the-pack The positive global trend makes me much more confident that it will happen in 1 more country.

It seems like the amount of ev cars sold between 1st quarter of 13 and 1st quarter of 14 has nearly doubled. This is the only consequtive period in the data provided below. Even if it is expected to double that number this year it becomes somewhere in the region of 4500-5000. Very unlikely to exceed 6000...

My initial numbers included plug-ins which is a grave error.  The total number of solely electric vehicles is much less.  It seems unlikely now that they will reach that number in purely electric cars. At this time, roughly 25,500 cars are electric in Germany out of an approximate 45M cars. 
http://www.dw.com/en/germany-to-boost-electric-car-incentives/a-19214176 EVs in Germany account for .2% of the market.  This graph shows the amount of EVs registered in Germany from Jan 13 to April 14.  Even with the incentives that Germany has put into place, I doubt that 6,000 EVs will be registered in 3Q 2016.  
http://insideevs.com/pure-electric-car-sales-in-germany-up-25-8-year-on-year-n-april/ In Q1 2015 Germany's Plug in + EV registrations were 0.6 % of total registrations at 4,520 cars. 
http://qz.com/447971/in-norway-one-in-three-new-cars-is-electric-in-the-us-its-one-in-100/ We are not quite at the tipping point for electric cars yet either.  Experts predict that sales will start to soar sometime after 2020 and maybe in 2025.  This is a obviously a prediction talking about something 10 years out which makes little sense to put a lot of stock into, however 3Q 2016 is close. And there is evidence that shows it will not happen by then.
http://www.behindenergy.com/how-electric-cars-will-cause-the-next-oil-crisis/7300/?lang=en

Electric cars are being registered more frequently in each of the least three years, but also more frequently in the later months of those years.  With the incentives to purchase these cars in Germany it seems likely that EV registrations will continue to increase in the coming quarters.  A 45% increase in '15 to 16' registrations shows that, however the forecast is asking specifically for the 3rd quarter results. 3rd quarter registrations improved last year at a rate roughly around 52%. It is my outside view that it can improve at that rate again (given the incentives) and will put 3Q results at around 8,500 registrations.  However, the numbers of registrations thus far in '16 have not been promising, so we can't assume these numbers will continue to grow at the same rate.

Anyone know if German government cars are included or when the Government buy cars etc as if they spend 100 million quickly it will make a huge difference to target. "another €100 million (US$113 million) would go toward purchasing electric cars for federal government fleets " https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#Germany. Anyone know if these count? Are government cars "registered"?

The sales-numbers for electric vehicles April and May 2016: April: 604 (total sales: 315,921) 
May: 574 (calculation: 0.02% of 286,931) Slight growth (+2,4%) compared to the same month last year (I think that's what it says)
No sign of a sales boost yet, the 'kaufprämie' started 1 May. August is traditionally a 'low sales' month. It's going to be hard to get to 6,000 registrations, I think.  Source: http://www.kba.de/DE/Presse/Pressemitteilungen/2016/Fahrzeugzulassungen/pm17_2016_n_05_16_pm_komplett.html?nn=716864

Just have a look on the Webpage of the Kraftstoffbundesamt. Just in May 286931 new Cars and 0,2% electric cars. So just estimate 600 cars per month is far away of needed cars of 2000 per month even if expect exponential growth. If you include hybrid cars than the number will be reached in a month.
The statistic from 2003 to 2015 says no, because in 2015 the delta to 2014 was 4.000 vehicles only (for the full year 2015.  The boom is not strong enough.

Following @dr-cankraut @BrianAhlborn @RF A jump in monthly sales of more than 100% is probably expecting too much. Please see dr-cankraut's comment about March sales being the best. People will prefer to buy the Hybrids with the subsidy. Maybe after the 300 Million subsidy package gets invested on the charging infrastructure, people will get more interested in BEVs. I would normally go to 5% on this question, but @mcmahonimal post has sufficiently confused me that I am sticking to 20% for now.
Steady growth through 2014, 2015 and the start of 2016. Larger sales towards the end of the year. Should comfortably exceed 6000 by 10-20%.

"another €100 million (US$113 million) would go toward purchasing electric cars for federal government fleets " https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#Germany.   Anyone know if these count? Are government cars "registered"? Any news if scheme has started?

Given current sales statistics: Q3-15, Q1-16, it's not gonna happen. Figure that there's gonna be marketing + promotions +ads following the introduction of new subsidy scheme, so then it might be possible. Total share was 0.3%, so marginal percentage increase makes the target.

- to clarify question I’m assuming it’s 6K EV sold/registered in Germany the 3Q2016 NOT cumulative
- Germany very eco-conscious +
- EV has very small market share currently 0.4% of German car market so plenty of room to increase +
- there is enough German auto manufacturers that make EV’s available so this won't be a limiting factor, shouldn’t be damaging to the German car industry (almost 25% of cars registered are German) +  Tesla is too expensive for this program
-German govt has stated goal of 1M vehicles on the road by 2020, to get there need growth to materially accelerate +
-Sweden is similarly eco conscious and introduced a similar incentive in 1Q12 which led to a 4x increase in unit sales so this is strong ++ The Norwegian example is not comparable because incentives there are much higher at 17K EUR 
-German subsidy is not that big in 4K EUR this is a negative but slightly higher for a pure electric vehicle (only 3K for hybrid) slight + so net this is a wash to slight negative IMO
-only question marks are: 
-why were German electric vehicle sales so weak in 1Q16 down 2% y/y after strong 100% y/y growth in 4Q15? I can only speculate that consumers anticipated this incentive being announced so there is some pent up demand so this is a +
-timing- incentive program starts in May and is first come first serve up to 400K cars in total which should last a few years but may have some impact on pulling in demand so slight +
- the May partial month EV registrations will give us an idea of the trajectory but the June full month number will give us clarity - 1200 is a good number for June IMO to get to 6K in 3Q16
The new Tesla is not out yet.
It will be close, but the pressure coming form the "failure" of German diesel technology to meet goals will put a premium on achieving goals for environmentally friendly cars.

My previous estimate of 13.5k can be seen here: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/237241 I recently saw that the German government expects 400,000 electric cars to be sold due to the subsidy. [http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/28/germany-subsidy-boost-electric-car-sales] We can use that as an estimate for the number of electric cars sold over a given time frame. Since the number is so large, we can make it an extra long time frame and say those 400k are sold over 10 years, meaning 40k/yr, or 10k per quarter. (1) This is on the same order of magnitude as my previous Fermi estimate, and still considerably greater than 6k. I'll stick with my initial 90% Yes for now, but I'll be interested to see June's sales numbers. (1) Looking at articles on it, it's not clear whether the 400k estimate refers to electric only or electric and plug-in hybrid, the latter of which is not included in this question. Following the links the Guardian says that in Norway in the few months preceding January 2014 around 1200 all-electric cars were being registered. (Some additional incentives such as free parking and no tolls were being offered.) The population of Norway is only 5 million compared to Germany's 80 million. Germany is already selling around 2700 all- electrics per month. Even though Norway is rather richer than Germany I'd expect that the famously green Germans ought to at least buy all-electric cars at a third of the Norwegian rate. That would mean sales of slightly over 6000 cars per month. (1200*1/3*80/5).
I don't think so in a country as Germany in which traditional car industry is very powerful

I believe the German government is pursuing this for many reasons (e.g., "dieselgate", environmental concerns from 40x pollution pumped in the air but those cars,  damage to German engineering ethos, etc.) and as such I believe they will push very hard to make sure there will be at least 6,000 registered vehicles. One of the tools in their arsenal is getting municipalities and government entities to make up any shortfalls.

The data I have so far.

there has been natural growth without the incentive each successive year from 2012 onward, a simple linear projection takes us to 3800 sales in Q3 2016, the incentive is generous. 31% of the unconventional market has been e-cars, government paying share of the incentive is 600,000 over 3 years, assume 31% market share is maintained at 4000 per car approx. 3877 e-cars per quarter are incentivised. Some buyers will have been buying e-cars anyway though - say 50% so 1900 additional e-cars in Q3.1900 plus 3800=5700 - sources of error are many - incentive is generous and might get some bigger uptake in 1st year, limit to how many cars can be supplied, a spike in demand may not be able to be accommodated at the factory. E-cars will have a limited appeal and conventional drivers are more likely to take the hybrid option - less change but similar incentive.

The automatic response would be no for a multitude of reasons. Germans love their luxury cars, companies own the vast majority of the expensive flot and there are very few German-made full-electric cars on the market which cover the needs of the customers. A minor price reduction will not cover their willingness to pay. So, some facts: http://www.kba.de/DE/Statistik/Fahrzeuge/Neuzulassungen/MonatlicheNeuzulassungen/2016/201604GV1monatlich/201604_nzbarometer/201604_n_barometer.html?nn=653844 In April 2016 (newest data), 604 full electric cars were registered. Q1+April had 2936 cars, and slightly down by 4% compared to 2015. For the 6000 hurdle to be surpasses, well more than 2000 / month or a plus of 333% need to be achieved. Looking into detail, even Telsa in not notable enough to get its own row in the official stats. Ii falls under the “others” category: http://www.kba.de/SharedDocs/Publikationen/DE/Statistik/Fahrzeuge/FZ/2016_monatlich/FZ11/fz11_2016_04_pdf.pdf?__blob=publicationFile&v=2 In the industry, there is also a strong seasonal effect. Spring (especially March) sees that highest sales as August people or on holiday, not buying cars: http://www.kba.de/DE/Presse/Pressemitteilungen/2011_2015/2015/Fahrzeugzulassungen/pm01_2015_n_12_14_pm_komplett.html Thus, even if the program picks-up sales the effect will be seen in Q2-2017. Tip: 5%
There is no electric vehicle charging infrastructure
German automotive engineering has been focusing on enhanced performance for EV, making their attraction and purchase more appealing.

http://www.best-selling-cars.com/electric/2016-germany-electric-hybrid-car-sales/ reveals the trend, though it says the sales of electric cars have slowed down in the first quarter of 2016, and reaching the figure of 6000 in the 3rd quarter alone may prove unlikely.
Germany is very proud of their car export economy they will buy the cars.

Certainly, the new subsidies of the German government will help - if not boost sales of electric vehicles. However, besides enthusiast citizens or people who like to show off with their new Tesla as beeing environmental friendly, rich and trendy , the battery technology has not yet reached the average German consumer. The battery technology still is not strong enough, nor user friendly. It would be, in case a battery had the size and weight of a book , clean, integrated in the dash board, standardized and emtpy ones could be exchanged at any filling station against a loaded one - against a fair fee. Today, small battery cars are rather used as second cars or city cars or for citizens with their job in a 10 mile distance (or retired ones). Germans who like to drive to Italy, Spain, France , etc. for vacation still depend on the engine driven car.  The enigine is one of the core competencies of German car industry, BMW even is called "Bavarian engine works" - the industry thus did and does not fully support battery cars, however takes the topic serios as newcomer car brands may replace traditional ones, in case they do not switch in the right time. 
In Germany more than 40% of energy production still comes from dirty burning fossile coal. Thus "battery cars" in Germany are probably the most "dirty cars" in terms of the environment! Only 100% non-fossile energy will make them green!
It is the wave of the future.   Also, Germany is a very big producer of autos, hence it is logical the Germans will be at the vanguard.
Data (if correct) talk about 23.000 BEV in Germany in 2015, without the new rebate scheme, so it's just more or less a matter of repeating the performance of last year.
Staying below consensus, mainly due to the still rather poor supporting infrastructure.
Historical sales & growth don't support. Incentive boost impact not assumed that strong, though, should check incentive size vs ave elec car price

I would guess third quarter sales of electric-only vehicles to be 3500-4000. The subsidy would need to have a big impact in order to propel sales above 6000. The first month we'll see the impact of the subsidy is June. I'll check back at that time. Nissan is augmenting the subsidy with 1000 euros of its own per car: http://www.automotiveworld.com/news-releases/nissan-sparks-interest-electric-vehicles-added-bonus-customers/

BEV cars sold in Q3 15 2,722
BEV cars sold in Q1 16 2,332
Growth rate 2013-14: 40.8
Growth rate 2014-15: 45.1
Growth rate needed to sell 6,00 in Q3 120%  So without the subsidy/ sudden improvement in infrastructure/ excitement over new model release there is no reason to believe BEVs can achieve that growth rate, especially considering their are only 25,500 BEVs registered in the first place (http://www.dw.com/en/germany-sets-out-major-cash-incentive-for-electric-car-buyers/a-19266326). So put it at say 6% to account for the law of small numbers. Sudden improvement in infrastructure: 0% given timeline
New model release: can't find any, new BMW will be sold in 2017, but give it 1% in case I missed something.
Subsidy: There are two price ranges 20,000 euros and 34,000 euros eligible (http://www.electriccarpledge.com/electric-cars/electric-cars-for-sale-in-germany/). A 4,000 subsidy is equivalent to only 12% for the more expensive range, so I think it is doubtful (4%) that could more than double the number of cars registered.
In the cheaper price range though the subsidy is a more material ie 20% off, however because the subsidised price is still more expensive then the non electric models, I will only attribute 8% chance of those making the difference. Total of 19% before adjustments: European commission decision on state aid -3%
Subsidy is valid until 600m euros are used up (or 150,000 sales assuming everyone goes for electric cars), so there is no need to rush to buy, especially given its the quietest quarter for car sales and their will be a slate of new model releases in 2017. -8%

the subsidy should raise demand but that's still a lot of ground to make up in one quarter. I think the subsidy will raise demand for domestically made electrics and away from foreign substitutes, (IOW, a change in price along the demand curve, but not necessarily shift demand upward.
Adoption of new technology takes longer than intuition says.

1. Expected Q3 2016 total sales: 800,000. [A1]
2. Electric car (BEV) registrations 2015: 12,363 (0.39% of total). [A2]
3. Expected BEV registrations: 3090.75 (from 1 and 2 above)
4. ev-volumes is projecting an 80% increase in PEV sales if the subsidy goes into effect May 2016. Assume BEV is similar. [A3]
5. Expected BEV registrations: 5560 (from 3 and 4 above) I believe the Kia Soul is the biggest variable here. Approx ~18% of the BEV market in 2015 wasn't "real German demand" [A4]. We have further evidence for this given Jan - April 2016 sales for the Soul are 132 (versus several thousand the previous quarter). If we back out Kia Souls from 2015, we'd have an expected 4559 BEV registrations.   So 4500 to 5500 seems like a reasonable 50% confidence interval.  I'll put the probability it's less than 4500 at 30%, reflecting that it may take a while for EU approval.
So P(>6000) is at most 20%. I'll say 12% for now. Things to watch going forward
**Is Kia above 131 gram CO2 limit?
If true, they'll import Souls to Germany and sell as used to Norway. It's a pretty neat trick actually. I looked up taxes and it appears to be 1% to import from Germany to Norway.  **Pent-up demand
Rumors of this were as early as 2/2016, so buyers might be holding off. I would not be surprised if the first month of the subsidy were substantially higher than subsequent months. As someone mentioned, the law is retroactive. But think most sensible Germans will wait till it's approved.

PEV = plug-in electric vehicle
2015 BEV vs. PEV registration: 12363 vs 11101
source: http://www.best-selling-cars.com/electric/2016-germany-electric-hybrid-car-sales/ A3. Assume "an instant implementation in 2016" means "an instant implementation in May 2016"
source: http://www.ev-volumes.com/country/germany/ A4. The "Scheme":
-- According to the KBA (federal vehicle agency), the Kia Soul EV is by far the most popular EV in Germany for 2015, selling 2459 so far this year and 1000 just in October 2015. This seems weird, since the car is nowhere to be seen on the road.
-- The Center for Automotive Research at the University of Duisburg has discovered that 91% (all of 2015 so far) or 99% (October 2015) of new Soul EVs in Germany were first registered to Kia dealers.
-- 2/3 of Soul EVs in Norway are "used" cars imported from Germany. Norway is a huge market for electric vehicles in general.
-- Kia dealers in DE register the Soul and sell in Norway as a used car
-- CO2 emission supercredits only count for the region where the vehicle is first registered.
-- According to the KBA, average emissions for all Kia vehicles sold in Germany dropped from 128 g CO2 to 112 g CO2 from September to October. According to the SPIEGEL, this is primarily achieved by the phantom EV registrations.
-- According to T&E (Transport & Environment, an NGO), Kia-Hyundai manages to avoid paying a €70m penalty by using this trick and staying 0.9 grams below the 131 gram CO2 limit. The DE subsidy requires ownership for 9 months, so not likely to respond to subsidy. I cannot verify "supply issues" keeping Soul sales low in  Q1 2016. April 2016 sales for the Kia Soul were 98 in Norway vs 24 in Germany. Looks like they are just prefering to ship to Norway directly. source: http://www.spiegel.de/auto/aktuell/hyundai-poliert-co2-flottenverbrauch-mit-kia-soul-ev-export-a-1064766.html

YOY Quarterly comparisons means 120% required change to meet the 6,000 BEV target whereas incentives apply May 2016 onwards and apply to Hybrids also. German total auto sales for 2015 grew approximately 4% YOY with no particular incentives and VW under the radar which may have suppressed a normalized growth cycle. Assuming auto sales in Germany grow @10% per year then BEV growth of 100%+ appears aggressively speculative. Starting with a conservative estimate, following monthly sales trends with latest incentive packages that can change my judgement

The sales ratios of battery-only to hybrids for 2015, Q1 of 2016, and both (2015+Q1 2016) are roughly:
2015:          1 to 2.72
2016 Q1:    1 to 4.55
Both:           1 to 2.99 Projecting sales based on these ratios means that to reach 6,000 battery-only sales, there would also be 
16,320 hybrids sold in Q3 (based on 2015), or
26,729 hybrids sold in Q3 (based on Q1 2016), or
17, 940 hybrids sold in Q3 (based on both 2015+2016). The sales of battery-only vehicles is quite erratic so there isn’t a solid correlation of battery-only to hybrid sales but either way the required number of hybrid sales to suggest that battery-only sales reach 6,000 is pretty high.

~90% of buyers opted for hybrids in Q1 and ~10% for "Stromers" (pure BEVs). Prime concern are the perceived vulnerability to run out of power somewhere between two distant charging stations: April sales show a distinct drop of -11% YTY in pure EV cars, and a +28% in hybrids (including plugins) [3]. I wonder whether the new subsidies will push the ~10% "stromer" crowd into a ~5% group. This is a gut call. I Lived in Germany for a while.  Fuel is expensive...really expensive!  So are new cars.  So is electricity.  Everything is expensive.  Average income is about 3500 euro a month.  They have wind mills all over the place that I think are mostly for show.  Car Registrations in 3rd Q in Germany is expected to be 261493 compared to 1st Q 315921 (actual) and 2 Q 282228.  A 4 thousand euro discount from the German Gov for an EV car is good but its all the other stuff that is complicated.  Germany also has a fairly efficient public transit system!  There are only 2638 EV charging stations.  It makes more sense to buy a hybrid versus just EV  I'm going to come in low at 33% and wait for the official 2Q registration numbers.

Napkin math/Fermi Estimation: €1 billion program, €600 million of which is going towards the new subsidy. Plug-in and Electric vehicles are close to the same sales (same order of magnitude) per the question's source. Plug-ins will receive €3k and full electric €4k. Assuming their sales-ratio stays constant, that's an average of €3.5k subsidy. €600 million/€3.5k=170k, the total number of cars that can be subsidized, assuming 100% efficiency (lol). Assuming half are electric, that's 85k electric vehicles covered by the new subsidy, or 21k/quarter if purchased over a year. As a quick check, there are about 3.5 million auto sales in Germany per year (.9M/quarter), so this would represent about 2% of their total market. While a big lurch, it's not completely out of the realm of possibility. Reasons to lower estimate: 
Purchases take longer to ramp up than a few months, as you have to save money to purchase a car. I think this is mostly counterbalanced by the fact that the subsidies are first-come, first-serve, encouraging early usage. Maybe only 80% in first full quarter compared to subsequent, or .8*21k=17k Efficiency of the subsidy < 100%. I have no great priors, but I think I remember seeing Medicare has less than 20% overhead, so make it only 80% efficient. .8*17k=13.5k Assuming this passes (the news sources seem pretty confident), this seems to be a somewhat safe Yes. No idea where I should be on my SD, but I think I have enough cushion worked in to allow a pretty confident Yes.
Trust has wained in traditional vehicles.  People will start to look at alternative cars thanks to the emissions scandal.

Following @Raisinville with initial forecast. I'm inclined to lean toward questionable acceptance (source of power, shifting tech, some of the real downsides that seem to be glossed over frequently). OTOH not a significantly higher number especially if there is a bleeding edge cachet involved.

Start at just under 50%, revisit when new data is available. Electric only BEVs increased almost 50% from 2014 To 2015 (8,522 to 12,363). Assuming the same increase for 2016Q3 is around 1,350 BEVs per month (even though 2016 Q1 data was slightly lower than 2015. Reasons electric BEVs may increase:
--4,000 euro subsidy. However, while electric BEVs increased around 50% from 2015, Plug-ins increased almost 3 times the 2015 numbers.  The plug ins have a 3,000 euro subsidy.  Hybrids are barred from the subsidies.  In an anti-Tesla (3rd most popular German electric) move, subsidies only apply to price tags less than 60,000 euros, which excludes all of Tesla's current models.
--150,000 charging stations (2016-2020) are being built through the government program at a cost of 300,000,000 euros. 
--100,000,000 euros to be spent on BEVs for government agencies, @ 50,000 (guess / BEV) that's about 2,000 BEVs. Reasons BEVs may not make the 6,000 Q3 target:
--Program may start in May, program issues and availability, etc may delay ramp up in sales.
--Reports that German customers prefer plug-ins as the recharge periods are shorter.  With a growth rate almost 6 times higher, plug-ins may get most of the subsidies.
--Reports that German customers are concerned that the new technology may be replaced within a few years.
Too soon for a surge of registrations. 3Q vacation months and eve of 2017 models argue for "later".

The government will decide this Wednesday (18 May 2016). There is quite a lot of opposition against the proposal - from their own 'scientific advisory council', among others - but it seems they will go ahead anyway and add some tax-deductions too. To reach 6,000 new cars in Q3, an huge increase in sales is needed. The plan would start in June, and sales in March (-11% YoY) have been lagging in anticipation of the new subsidies. Sales in April and May will probably fall behind (YoY) as well. So there may be a catch-up effect (in Q3) on top of the normal growth in this market. See (in German): http://www.welt.de/newsticker/dpa_nt/infoline_nt/wirtschaft_nt/article155427929/Neben-Kaufpraemie-kommt-auch-10-Jahres-Steuerbonus.html
And for the objections against the proposal: http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Ministerialbeirat-warnt-vor-Kaufpraemie-fuer-E-Autos-3209418.html

Electric (battery-only) vehicles (at discounts of 4,000 euros) will be competing heavily with Hybrids (at discounts of 3,000 euros).  With ample fuel supplies and low prices, I don't see a logical aversion to hybrids.  There is too much downside risk in buying a Battery-only as compared to buying a Hybrid. There is also a lack of consistency in sales of Battery-only vehicles.  And 6k in a quarter is almost 3x Q1, and about half of 2015.   I just don't see it happening.
